datafield.subfield: Around the world in 80 days (Motion picture : 1956)
Michael Todd Co., Inc.; directed by Michael Anderson ; produced by Michael Todd ; screenplay by James Poe, John Farrow, and S.J. Perelman.
20 film reels of 20 on 12 (approximately 182 min., approximately 16,380 ft.) :
Copyright: Michael Todd Company, Inc.; 17Oct56; LP9127.
Originally filmed in Todd A-O widescreen format.
Based on the novel, Tour du monde en quatre-vingts jours, by Jules Verne.

Associate producers, William Cameron Menzies, Kevin O'Donovan McClory ; music, Victor Young ; photography, Lionel Lindon ; art direction, James Sullivan, Ken Adam ; set decoration, Ross Dowd ; costume designer, Miles White ; choreographer, Paul Godkin ; sound, Joseph Kane ; special effects, Lee Zavitz ; general manager, Percy Guth ; executive assistant, Samuel Lambert ; technical consultant, Schuyler A. Sanford ; unit manager, Frank Fox ; screen credits design, Saul Bass.

David Niven, Cantinflas, Robert Newton, Shirley MacLaine, John Carradine, Finlay Currie, Ronald Squire, Basil Sydney, A.E. Matthews, Trevor Howard, Charles Boyer, Joe E. Brown, Martine Carol, Charles Coburn, Ronald Colman, Melville Cooper, Noel Coward, Reginald Denny, Andy Devine, Marlene Dietrich, Luis Miguel Dominguin, Fernandel, Sir John Gielgud, Hermione Gingold, Jose Greco, Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Glynis Johns, Buster Keaton, Evelyn Keyes, Beatrice Lillie, Peter Lorre, Edmund Lowe, Mike Mazurki, Col. Tim McCoy, Victor McLaglen, John Mills, Alan Mowbray, Robert Morley, Jack Oakie, George Raft, Gilbert Roland, Cesar Romero, Frank Sinatra, Red Skelton, Harcourt Williams.
According to the MI Film and Television catalog card, viewing prints, copies 1 and 2 have magnetic sound tracks

In 1872, the precise, punctual English gentleman, Phileas Fogg, places a 20,000-pound wager with several fellow members of London Reform Club, insisting that he can go around the world in eighty days. Together with his resourceful valet Passepartout, Fogg sets out from Paris via balloon. Meanwhile, suspicion grows that Fogg has stolen his 20,000 pounds from Bank of England. Inspector Fix is sent out to pursue Fogg and bring him to justice. Hopscotching around the globe, Fogg pauses in Spain, where Passepartout engages in a comic bullfight. In India, they rescue young widow Princess Aouda from being forced into committing suicide so that she may join her late husband. They visit Hong Kong, Japan, San Francisco, and the Wild West. Only hours short of winning his wager, Fogg is arrested. Though exonerated of the bank robbery charges, he has lost everything, except the love of Aouda. But salvation is at hand when Passepartout discovers that, by crossing the International Date Line, there's still time to reach the Reform Club.
Summary derived from synopsis on Allmovie WWW site.
Detailed inventory of film components in the AFI/Taylor (Elizabeth) Collection can be found in the MI acquisition file.
LC's 70 mm non-viewing print is a Todd A-O print.
LC also holds a 12 in. videodisc viewing copy in the LC Purchase Collection.

Sources used: Taves and Michaluk, The Jules Verne encyclopedia, p. 223-225; Michael Todd's around the world in 80 days almanac; Library of Congress information bulletin, October 21, 1996, p. 388-390; Allmovie.com, viewed July 27, 2023; Variety, October 18, 1956, p. 3 & 7, viewed October 17, 2023 via Variety Archive.

A drama of the problems of a wealthy but decadent family in the South. A one-time college athlete finds it difficult to withdraw from the pass, and live as a man of responsibility. His friend tries to betray his wife, but is destroyed by him with drink. The hero is a third man who struggles to maintain a large farm, living as a good example to the others.

It's been said that there are two sides to every story. In the case of divorce, these two sides are often drastically different. In the first half of the Divorce his/divorce hers set, Richard Burton demonstrates the husband's point of view as he goes through divorce proceedings with his soon-to-be ex-wife. In the second half ... the wife offers up her perspective of going through a divorce from her husband.

analyses of efficiency, effectiveness and donor coordination /
Foreign policy of the United States
Edited, reformatted and augmented versions of Congressional Research Service publications: February 13, 2013, February 5, 2013, and February 10, 2011.

Does Foreign Aid Work? Efforts to Evaluate U.S. Foreign Assistance / Marian Leonardo Lawson, CRS -- Foreign Aid: International Donor Coordination of Development Assistance / Marian Leonardo Lawson, CRS -- Foreign Aid: An Introduction to U.S. Programs and Policy / Curt Tarnoff, Marian Leonardo Lawson, CRS.

Foreign assistance is a fundamental component of the international affairs budget and is viewed by many as an essential instrument of U.S. foreign policy. Since the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, foreign aid has increasingly been associated with national security policy. U.S. foreign aid policy has developed around three primary rationales: national security, commercial interests, and humanitarian concerns. These broad rationales are the basis for the myriad objectives of U.S. assistance, including promoting economic growth, reducing poverty, improving governance, expanding access to health care and education, promoting stability in conflictive regions, promoting human rights, strengthening allies, and curbing illicit drug production and trafficking. This book provides analyses of the efficiency, effectiveness and donor coordination outcomes relating to foreign aid.
Foreign policy of the United States.

The story of Texas rancher Bick Benedict, his society wife, and three generations of their land-rich Texas sons and daughters as their family rivalry with cowboy and (later oil tycoon) Jett Rink unfolds across two generations. A monumental drama of family strife, racial bigotry, and conflict between cattle barons and newly-rich oil tycoons.

Special features include: introduction by George Stevens, Jr. ; commentary by George Stevens, Jr., Ivan Moffat and Stephen Farber ; Documentary: George Stevens : a filmmaker's journey ; George Stevens : filmmakers who knew him, Memories of Giant, and Return to Giant ; New York premiere TV special, Hollywood premiere featurette and behind the camera segments ; stills and documents galleries ; original/reissue theatrical trailers ; and more.

Key issues in childhood and youth studies /
edited by Derek Kassem, Lisa Murphy, and Elizabeth Taylor.

In the beginning? The origins of childhood / John Clarke -- The building blocks : construction of childhood / Shirley J Pressler -- A mixed life : race, racism, and mixed heritage / Derek Kassem -- Mind games : the psychology of the child / Diahann Gallard -- Inborn or bred : the development of speech and language / Lisa Murphy -- Coming of age : childhood sexuality / John Clarke -- The nanny state? Children and the notion of risk / Andrew Kennedy -- Not seen, not heard : the child and protection / Lynne Kendal -- The parent of last resort : life as a looked-after child / Derek Kassem -- Healthy in body, healthy in? / John Harrison -- The devil wears a hoodie : the social construction of deviant identities / John Robinson -- Up against the wall : the testing regime of childhood / Terry Wrigley -- Rightfully mine! The rights of the child / Heather Montgomery -- The have-not nots : childhood and youth poverty in the UK / Diane Grant -- Brutalized childhoods : the Palestinian experience / Samir Qouta -- The death of childhood : childhood in the context of HIV/AIDS / Gabriella Torstensson -- To go or to starve : moving for a better life / Sam Punch.

"Middle-aged Frederick Egerman has been patiently waiting a year for his young bride Anne to consummate their marriage. But unbeknownst to Frederick, his son Erich is also in love with Anne. To complicate matters, Frederick's former mistress Desiree Armfeldt arrives in town--but Desiree is having a clandestine affair with the husband of the Countess Mittelheim! The mismatched couples in this delightful bedroom farce are all invited to a country estate where their lives (and loves) are inevitably sorted out."--Container.
Sources used: videodisc container; Internet movie database, November 7, 2022.

George and Alice are poor and lonely people who find comfort in each other. While Alice progresses to real love for George, he finds love elsewhere within the wealthy social set to which he aspires. When the pregnant Alice appears at the mountain lake resort where George and the socialite Angela, his fiancee, are on vacation, his confused emotions lead him to take Alice into a boat with the intention of drowning her. He can't go through with it, but a misstep ends in Alice's drowning anyway. George is arrested, convicted of premeditated murder, and condemned to the electric chair.

William Shakespeare's comic look at the war between the sexes in the 16th century. When Petruchio, a poverty stricken gentleman from Verona, seeks a rich wife in Padua, he winds up with Katharina, a self-willed shrew. Their honeymoon becomes a humourous battle of wits and insults, with Kate as determined to maintain her independence as Petruchio is to "tame" her. But when the newlyweds return to Padua, Petruchio wagers that his Kate is now the most obedient of wives. Kate helps Petruchio win his wager, but she shows she has found a more effective way of dominating her mate.
Part of summary from videocassette box.
Based on the play by William Shakespeare.
On disc jacket: Pioneer Video, Inc. 30110.

"Ayib is a white cheese that looks similar to cottage cheese. Many would describe its flavor as mild. To enhance the taste of ayib, rue, butter (niter kibbeh), and spices such as powdered cayenne pepper, black pepper and salt are often added separately, or in combination. Ayib can be tossed with cooked vegetables and collard greens (as at the end of the story on the children's plate). Some Ethiopians stir yogurt with the spiced cheese, giving it a taste and consistency similar to Greek feta cheese. According to Ethiopian-Swedish chef Marcus Samuelsson, ayib is "simple to make, it's wonderful on its own, spread on a piece of injera or when used to balance the sharpness of heavily spiced foods." A side dish of cool creamy ayib goes well with the spicy taste of Ethiopian shiro, stews (wats), alichas and fitfits. Mixed together the smooth sour flavor of ayib balances with the hot spicy main dishes common in Ethiopia to create the delicious tates that Ethiopian people around the world know and love. In Ethiopia the herb rue (tenadam) is commonly used to enhance flavor. Rue is most often mixed with soft, spreadable cheeses like ayib. Rue is most commonly used to flavor coffee in Ethiopia; sprigs of rue are steeped in coffee and give it a hint of citrus flavor. When used in cooking, the herb should be removed before serving a dish. Steeping the herb for a few minutes in broth or sauce will make sure people taste less of Rue's bitter taste and more of its citrusy flavor. Part of the rue plant is also used to make berbere and shiro and to calm colicky babies. Rue can be poisonous to the body, so it is important not to take in too much of the herb"--
the origin of some of Ethiopia's best foods in English and Somali /

"When mama milks the family cow, everyone eats! First, there is fresh milk. With a little time, there is yogurt! With a little work, there is butter that can be added to shirro. There is buttermilk that can be turned into ayib (cheese). And finally, there is whey. Discover how much delicious food one cow can produce in our sweet look at household food production in Ethiopia"--

"This story takes one man in Ethiopia's experience with a dog to show ways that even weak and ignored members of our world can turn out to be important and worthy of honor. The role of animals in everyday life is different around the world. There can still be fear and mistrust of animals like dogs in many places. Side by side dual-language text supports emerging readers develop vocabulary and fluency"--

"One Ethiopian woman with disabilities who never gave up is Berhane Daba, Ethiopian Women with Disabilities National Association president and founder. EWDNA was created to deliver equal rights and empower disabled women by providing them with skills, opportunities, and inclusion in society. She advocates for equal access for women and people of disability so that they can reach their full potential through rehabilitation, education and skills training, while promoting mobility and accessibility. She is passionate about overcoming such obstacles because she has conquered them herself. When Berhane was four years old, she was diagnosed with polio and was left unable to walk. As a result of her disability, Berhane was placed in an orphanage in Addis Ababa. There, she was provided access to an education. Upon graduation from Kechene orphanage high school, Berhane received a diploma and became a librarian at the National Museum. Daba views gaining an education as her greatest opportunity to live an independent lifestyle. She continued her education at Admas University where she received a Bachelor of Science degree in Information and CommunicationTechnology. While at university, Berhane organized a small group of disabled women who also refused the accept the limits placed on them by society. Together they worked to provide support for women who lacked access to educational and professional opportunities. Since founding the Ethiopian Women with Disabilities National Association in 1995, Berhane and her 7 founding friends, worked to expand the organization's member base from its original eight members to over 2,000. Beyond providing technical and vocational training, EWDNA offers counseling and guidance services to further empower members to confidently enter the workforce. She has seen some changes in attitudes towards disabilities in the course of her life. She says, "People are witnessing that disability is not a curse and that with the right support system, which for that matter everyone needs, disability can be overcome.""--
the power of perseverance in English and Somali /
Yoseph Ayalew, Rabia Iqbal, Caroline Kurtz, Jane Kurtz, Kenny Rasmussen, Ellenore Angelidis, Elizabeth Spor Taylor, Abdi Mohamed Hassen, Mastewal Abera, Woubeshet Ayenew, Beth Crow.

"Life is full of challenges, but people are full of grit and determination. If there is no football to play with, we can make one! If we want to run faster, we can practice! If we want to learn, we can listen! Sometimes we need tools or accommodations to help us overcome obstacles, like wheelchairs or sign language or sighted guides. But regardless of the particular challenges we face, we can all grow, learn and thrive. Our different abilities comes with different gifts and assets as well, and diversity in any community brings strength. Whatever our goals, our determination and perseverance can help us reach them"--

"Thank You Trees, written by author Caroline Kurtz, is a heartfelt appreciation of trees and their importance in Ethiopian culture. From mango and coffee trees to trees grown for wood or shade, trees are a vital part of the Ethiopian environment. While deforestation and climate change pose significant threats to the health and survival of African trees, countries like Ethiopia organize mass tree-planting programs. This beautiful tribute to trees is colorfully illustrated by young students and printed in English and Kiswahili to support bilingual readers. Vibrant paper collage and rich watercolors show indigenous Ethiopian trees and plants while simple, bilingual text describes the diverse roles that trees play in everyday Ethiopian life. Part of the dual-language Ready Set Go series of books from Open Hearts, Big Dreams to provide colorful, culturally relevant children's books in indigenous Ethiopian languages"--

"The biggest plant on our planet is the baobab tree, an enormous "upside down" tree that can live for thousands of years! The baobab tree is used often in Ethiopian culture as an important food and resource for boats, rope, dyes and medicine. But the baobab trees of Africa are dying. Find out more about the ancient Ethiopian baobab forests in our latest #readysetgo title"--

"The Nile perch is a lonely fish. Large and intimidating, it tries to make friends with the other Nile residents. But the hippo, puffer fish, electric catfish and even the crocodile all swim away. But when the lonely perch pursues the crocodile, it learns the danger of basing its self-worth upon the opinion of others. Based on an Anywaa (Anuak) folktale, this story teaches children not to judge others by their appearance"--

"We rely on volunteers to illustrate most of our books. April Phillips has illustrated a number of our favorite books. We are delighted to offer readers a chance to enjoy a number of her titles in this compilation. From April Phillips: My journey to becoming a professional artist goes back to the beginning. One of my first memories as a child was drawing crayon pictures of cats on our hallway wall. I probably got in trouble for that, but I also knew deep inside my mother was very pleased that I displaying an early talent, as she was an extremely talented artist her-self. Growing up I would sit by her side and watch in awe as she would make a blank page come to life with just a pencil or paintbrush. It was her enthusiasm and encouragement through the years that lead me to become an art major in college. I graduated with a BFA in graphic design and shortly thereafter moved to San Francisco and enjoyed a career as an advertising art director. After many years of working in the field, I was able to return to my fine art roots and I dove into the study of academic drawing, oil painting, and figurative sculpture. In addition, when my boys were young, I established and taught an after-school art pro-gram for elementary school students where I had the pleasure of passing my enthusiasm for creating art to the next generation. I was introduced to Open Hearts Big Dreams through my twin boys basketball coach, Michael Angelidis, whose daughter Leyla was the inspiration for all these efforts. I then met Jane Kurtz, OHBD Creative lead, who grew up in Ethiopia and showed me how my creativity and artistic skills could impact the lives of children on the other side of the world. My eyes were opened to the challenges the country Ethiopia experiences with literacy and the inequity of opportunity compared to where I live. The Angelidis family, Jane Kurtz and other OHBD team members I met taught me that part of the problem was the complete lack of children's early reader books in Ethiopian kids' first language. In the business world I had created art to sell products. But donating my art to create books that could inspire a child to learn to read, and perhaps change the story of their lives, has been much more meaningful to me. And, when I have the opportunity to see a photo of a precious Ethiopian child looking intently through one of my books, it's amazingly satisfying"--
The knowledge industry in the United States, 1960-1980 /

an epic migration in Somali and English /

"The Painted Lady Butterfly begins its life as a tiny caterpillar. Some of them begin their lives in the Gullele Botanical Garden in Ethiopia, the start of an epic migration that will take them across the Great Pyramids of Egypt and deep into Europe, only to return to Ethiopia once again. With plenty of details about the life cycle and migration of these beautiful bugs for curious kids"--
Carol Settgast, Jane Kurtz, Carol Settgast, Sheridan Elementary School, Caroline Kurtz, Jane Kurtz, Elizabeth Spor Taylor, Kenny Rasmussen, Yoseph Ayalew, Mastewal Abera, Woubeshet Ayenew, Beth Crow.

"In 2009, scientists in the United Kingdom set up a citizen science project where ordinary people could help unlock the mystery of where U.K. painted lady butterflies went every autumn. The answer was an amazing 9,000-mile round trip journey from Africa to the Arctic Circle, the longest insect migration journey ever discovered. This Ready Set Go (RSG) book also had a long journey to reach publication. Many people helped to research, write, illustrate, and translate it. Many others will print and distribute this book to children in Ethiopia and around the world. Many of those children will be inspired to plant more flowers that butterflies need to be able to survive. The Project Manager for The Journey of Butterflies, Carol Settgast, met Jane Kurtz and other Ethiopia Reads volunteers in Ethiopia in 2010, during a cultural trip for educators. Carol has volunteered with Ethiopia Reads ever since. (The Ethiopia Reads Ethiopian staff will work with Carol on planning science and reading events, using this book to help Ethiopian children grow their understand of butterfly life.) While Carol was the librarian at Sheridan Elementary School in Junction City, Kansas, she helped students write Help! one of the first Ready Set Go Books. In 2021, Jane Kurtz did an author visit at Sheridan Elementary School and this new book began its long journey supported by many people-just as The Journey of Butterflies shows a long migration that can take about six generations of individual insects"--
Little night music. Selections. [Sound recording] [from old catalog]
Little night music. [Motion picture] [from old catalog]
Hide and seek at Kafta Sheraro national park :
a night on an ethiopian wildlife reserve in anuak and english /
Elizabeth Spor Taylor, Elizabeth Spor Taylor, Caroline Kurtz, Jane Kurtz, Kenny Rasmussen, Jekap Omod, Beth Crow.

"When the sun sets over the pristine waters of the Kafta Sheraro reserve, the demoiselle crane tucks its head and goes to sleep. But the warthog and the civet are just coming out to play! Meet fascinating Ethiopia animals like the red-necked ostrich, the honey badger, the caracal and the majestic elephants who pass through the Kafta Sheraro on their long journey across Africa. Colorful watercolor and paper collage fill the pages of our bilingual picture book, and side-by-side text helps bilingual readers develop fluency"--
Hide and seek at Kafta Sheraro National Park :
a night on an Ethiopian wildlife reserve in Somali and English /
Elizabeth Spor Taylor, Elizabeth Spor Taylor, Caroline Kurtz, Jane Kurtz, Kenny Rasmussen, Abdi Mohamed Hassen, Beth Crow.

"When the sun sets over the pristine waters of the Kafta Sheraro reserve, the demoiselle crane tucks its head and goes to sleep. But the warthog and the civet are just coming out to play! Meet fascinating Ethiopia animals like the red-necked ostrich, the honey badger, the caracal and the majestic elephants who pass through the Kafta Sheraro on their long journey across Africa. Colorful watercolor and paper collage fill the pages of our bilingual picture book, and side-by-side text helps bilingual readers develop fluency"--
how to be an inclusive family in Anuak and English /
Elizabeth Spor Taylor, Yoseph Ayalew, Alex Regassa, Caroline Kurtz, Jane Kurtz, Kenny Rasmussen, Jekap Omod, Mastewal Abera, Woubeshet Ayenew, Beth Crow.

"In Ethiopia, families divide the work required to maintain the household. Drying out dung for cooking fires or insulation, preparing meals, tending livestock and caring for other family members are all important tasks. Every member of the family can help, and supportive families learn how to balance their skills and abilities to ensure that everything gets done. An inclusive family also ensures that each member feels valued and respected, with responsibilities and duties that match their skills, regardless of their differences. Take a peek into the daily life of an inclusive Ethiopian family with diverse skills in our colorful bilingual early reader. Bright illustrations bring the daily life of a visually impaired Ethiopian girl into focus as she goes about her day, and how she supports (and is supported by) the loved ones around her"--
how to be an inclusive family in Somali and English /
Elizabeth Spor Taylor, Yoseph Ayalew, Alex Regassa, Caroline Kurtz, Jane Kurtz, Kenny Rasmussen, Abdi Mohamed Hassen, Mastewal Abera, Woubeshet Ayenew, Beth Crow.

"In Ethiopia, families divide the work required to maintain the household. Drying out dung for cooking fires or insulation, preparing meals, tending livestock and caring for other family members are all important tasks. Every member of the family can help, and supportive families learn how to balance their skills and abilities to ensure that everything gets done. An inclusive family also ensures that each member feels valued and respected, with responsibilities and duties that match their skills, regardless of their differences. Take a peek into the daily life of an inclusive Ethiopian family with diverse skills in our colorful bilingual early reader. Bright illustrations bring the daily life of a visually impaired Ethiopian girl into focus as she goes about her day, and how she supports (and is supported by) the loved ones around her"--
how to make Ethiopia's favorite snack in Somali and English /
Elizabeth Spor Taylor, Elizabeth Spor Taylor, Caroline Kurtz, Jane Kurtz, Kenny Rasmussen, Beth Crow, Abdi Mohamed Hassen.

"Young friends teach us how to make kolo in this simple, informative cookbook for young bilingual readers. Colorful paintings of the tools and ingredients needed to make this beloved snack of Ethiopians of all ages. Side by side dual language text in Somali and English support emerging bilingual readers with developing vocabulary and identifying key words. Step by step instructions with colorful pictures are easy to follow and fun to learn. Sweet or spicy, kolo is a delicious part of Ethiopian culture and commerce. Young readers will be eager to try the recipe themselves, and with a few simple ingredients you can enjoy the taste of Ethiopia while you explore this charming book. Part of the Open Hearts Big Dreams goal of increasing literacy in indigenous Ethiopian languages"--
where children live in English and Somali /
Elizabeth Spor Taylor, Woubeshet Ayenew, Haile Lijam, Caroline Kurtz, Jane Kurtz, Kenny Rasmussen, Abdi Mohamed Hassen, Mastewal Abera, Woubeshet Ayenew, Beth Crow.

"Ethiopia is full of diverse cultures and communities, and there are many kinds of dwellings to live in. Houses made of sticks, tall condominiums, complex thatched roofs and mud walls are just some of the many beautiful architectural styles that decorate the countryside. Children in Ambo, Gambela, Afar, Gode and Addis Ababa may all live in different styles of houses, but all of them find joy and play in their surroundings. Detailed watercolor illustrations by Haile Lijam fill the pages of this appreciation of Ethiopian design and ingenuity"--
how to get around in Ethiopia in Anuak and English /
Elizabeth Taylor, Haile Lijam, Beth Molla, Caroline Kurtz, Jane Kurtz, Kenny Rasmussen, Jekap Omod, Jordy Farrell, Beth Crow.

"Whether you take a taxi, a mule or a bajaj, there are lots of ways to travel in Ethiopia. What's the best way to get to the mountains, mosque, church or school? What if we want to go somewhere far away or just down the street? Detailed, playful illustrations capture the beauty and diversity of Ethiopian culture as we follow pairs of Ethiopian children as they navigate their world by car, train and bicycle. Side by side text in Amharic and English support emerging bilingual readers as they build vocabulary and develop fluency, while engaging illustrations capture young attentions. Ready, Set, Go! books are part of Open Hearts Big Dreams larger mission of increasing literacy in indigenous Ethiopian languages like Amharic, Tigrinya and Afaan Oromo"--
author : Elizabeth Taylor ; illustrators: Haile Lijam and Beth Molla.

"Whether you take a taxi, a mule or a bajaj, there are lots of ways to travel in Ethiopia. What's the best way to get to the mountains, mosque, church or school? What if we want to go somewhere far away or just down the street? Detailed, playful illustrations capture the beauty and diversity of Ethiopian culture as we follow pairs of Ethiopian children as they navigate their world by car, train and bicycle. Side by side text in Kiswahili and English support emerging bilingual readers as they build vocabulary and develop fluency, while engaging illustrations capture young attentions. Ready, Set, Go! books are part of Open Hearts Big Dreams larger mission of increasing literacy in indigenous Ethiopian languages like Amharic, Tigrinya and Afaan Oromo"--
The far islands and other cold places :
travel essays of a Victorian lady /
by Elizabeth Taylor ; James Taylor Dunn, editor.
Elizabeth Taylor ; with a new introduction by Paul Bailey.
"First published in Great Britain by Peter Davies Ltd., 1957"--Verso t.p.
Elizabeth Taylor ; with an introduction by Valerie Martin.

Mrs. Lippincote's house, with its mahogany furniture and yellowing photographs, stands as a reminder of all the certainties that have vanished with the advent of war. Temporarily, this is home for Julia, who has joined her husband Roddy at the behest of the RAF. Although she can accept the pomposities of service life, Julia's honesty and sense of humor prevent her from taking her role as seriously as her husband might wish; for Roddy, merely love cannot suffice--he needs homage as well as admiration. And Julia, while she may be a most unsatisfactory officer's wife, is certainly no hypocrite.
RSL Card has both call #'s printed.
